quote: Colonel.
(smiling in spite of    herself)   Odo, I wish you'd stop doing   that.
Doing what?
Calling me by my rank. I was    promoted two months ago.    Besides, it sounds so... formal.
Has Admiral Ross -- or should I    say Bill -- arrived yet?
The admiral's ship is due to    arrive in three hours. I wish I    knew what he wants to see me    about.
Maybe he's bringing good news.    We could certainly use some.
Don't get your hopes up. There    was something in the tone of his    voice...
Something ominous?
Something... pleasant. He was    going out of his way to be    nice...
I see...
Whatever he's coming to tell me,    he knows I'm not going to like it.
How can you be so sure?
It comes with the job.
I'm serious. Sitting in the    Captain's Chair, having that kind    of responsibility... it focuses    you...
I'll take your word for it.
(with growing     frustration)    How many days have they been    sitting there?
Three.
I can remember when the cult of    the Pah-wraiths was considered a    joke... now those red armbands    are appearing all over Bajor.    It's like everyone's gone crazy.
A lot of people feel abandoned by    the Prophets...
Believe me, I know how they feel.    But that's no excuse to turn to    hate and fear.
In times of trouble, some people    find comfort in hate and fear.    (re: the     supplicants)
If you'd like, I can charge them   with loitering and have them   removed from the station.
What good would that do?       I keep thinking... if the   Emissary were here, things might   be different.
I would've thought we'd have    heard from Captain Sisko by now.
Not a word in three months.
I realize things may seem bleak    at the moment, but there's    always hope...
Since when did you become such    an optimist?
Must have been that day, in    front of Quark's, when we kissed    for the first time.
That was some kiss, wasn't it?
Changed my life.
Gentlemen, we are home.
There should be a law against    convoy duty lasting more than    ten days.
I'll say one thing for guarding    convoys -- it's usually a lot    safer than being on the front    lines.
Is that why you joined    Starfleet, ensign? To be safe?
I didn't mean that the way it    sounded, sir...
In wartime, it's a soldier's    duty to fight.
Yes, sir.

The invasion of Cardassia has    ground to a halt while our    casualties continue to mount. It    is a time for warriors to do    great deeds. To triumph in    glorious battle -- not waste away    protecting shipments of    stembolts!
I hope Commander Worf doesn't    think I'm afraid to fight.
Relax, Nog. Don't take it so    personally -- Worf's just going    through a hard time.
He needs to focus on something    other than Jadzia. I hate to    admit it, but combat duty just    might do the trick.
The Defiant will be going into    battle soon enough. Then Worf    can be happy and the rest of us    can be miserable.
It's not that I'm afraid to    fight... it's just that I don't    want to die.         I wish Captain Sisko were here.
So do I, ensign. So do I.
(to the first    customer)   If I were you, I'd order the   crawfish etoufee.    (to the second    customer)   And if it's good enough for him,   it's good enough for you.
I think table five is ready to order.
He's been at that piano since    seven o'clock this morning.
Customers seem to like it.
Grandpa...
I'm worried too, but he's got    something to work out... best we    leave him alone.
We've left him alone for three    months! He said he came here to    figure out a way to contact the    Prophets... to make things right.    But so far he hasn't even left    the restaurant.
Dad? What is it? What's wrong?
Dad!
I had a vision... from the    Prophets. I was on Tyree, in    the desert... digging in the    sand...        I uncovered a face... the face    of a woman.
And?
That's all...
Who was she?
I've never seen her before...    but now I know why I came back    here. I have to find her,    Jake... I have to.
Colonel, I really don't think    you have anything to be    concerned about. I've met    Senator Cretak and I found her    to be... very cooperative.
For a Romulan.
Cretak's a strong supporter of    the Alliance... and we need that    kind of support if we're going    to win this war.

I don't care if the Romulans    were the only thing standing    between us and total    annihilation, I'd still think    twice about letting them    establish a military presence    here on the station.
(with some     exasperation)    We're just talking about a few    offices for the senator and her    staff.
And a contingent of personal    guards.
A dozen people, at most.    Besides, it's only a temporary    arrangement -- until the end of    the war.
And when will that be?
Let's get one thing straight,    colonel. I came here as a    courtesy to you. This decision    has already been made.
And I have to live with it.
That's right.
You've done a fine job, taking    over for Captain Sisko.
I'm just keeping his seat warm.
You still think he'll be back?
Don't you?
I'll be in touch.
As you can see, we've halted the    Klingon advance against Monac    Four.        We estimate their casualties at    over thirty percent.
They should've been higher.        Nevertheless, congratulations    Damar. The enemy remains    bottled up within the Chin'toka    system. And there they'll stay    until we destroy them.
I'd offer you a glass, but I    know how much you dislike kanar.
I'm beginning to think you like    it too much.
I wouldn't trust a Cardassian    who doesn't enjoy a glass of    kanar every once in awhile.
Tell me, Damar -- when you're    alone, do you even bother with a    glass, or do you just drink that    swill directly from the bottle?
It depends on my mood. And    right now, I feel like    celebrating. We owe Gul Dukat a    debt of gratitude.
Unfortunately, I agree. Somehow,    releasing that Pah-wraith into    the wormhole has shifted the    momentum of the war in our favor.
Do you ever wonder what's going    on in there... the wormhole, I    mean.
Not really.
The Prophets and the Pah-wraiths    locked in some kind of celestial    battle... it's fascinating.
I never realized you had such a    vivid imagination.
There's a lot about me you don't    know.
Just remember, having too much    imagination can be... dangerous.
(trying to engage     him)   Dad -- Grandpa and I are going   over to Armstrong Park to listen   to some music. Want to come?
You two go ahead.
What's that?
The woman I saw in my vision...   I don't want to forget her face.
I'll see you in the morning.
Hey... I've seen her.
Where?
In a photograph...
Here she is. I knew it.
It's her, isn't it?
I don't understand... who is    she?
Why don't you ask Grandpa?
Ask me what?
This woman --
Where'd you get that?
I found it last week when I was    cleaning out the storage room. I    meant to ask you about it.
Who is she, Dad?
She's no one, you hear me? No    one at all.
Hey, pallie -- where you been    keeping yourself.
Convoy duty.
Doesn't sound very exciting.
It wasn't.
Well, if you're looking for a    little action, you've come to    the right place. What do you    say we hit the craps tables? Or    maybe a little blackjack to get    the blood pumping?
Sing the song.
I don't think that's such a good   idea...
Sing the song.
C'mon, pallie... why rub salt on    an open wound?
You're a hologram. You're    programmed to do as I say. Sing    the song.
It's your dime, pallie.
Park it right there.
And don't say I didn't warn you.        Which reminds me of a story Joey    once told me --
(interrupting, a     threat)    Sing!
(to the band, a la     Joey Bishop)    Son of a gun, I think he means    it.
This monitor is still off-line.    I want it operational within the    hour.
I hope all the chairs on this    station aren't this    uncomfortable.
I'm afraid they are.
But don't worry, you'll get used    to them.
I'm sure I will.    (stands up to greet     Kira)    You must be Colonel Kira.
I'm sorry I wasn't there to    greet you at the airlock when    you arrived. I was --
No need to explain, Colonel.    I'm sure you're quite busy.
I hope you find your    accommodations satisfactory.    Other than the chairs, of course.
I'm sure we'll be quite    comfortable here. I trust that    won't be a problem for you.
Meaning what?
My people have a reputation for    arrogance. I'm afraid it's well-   earned.
But you're different. Or so    Admiral Ross tells me.
The admiral and I have a good    working relationship. I hope to    have a similar one with you.
I'd like nothing more.
Then I look forward to working    with you toward our common goal    -- the destruction of the Dominion.
Worf did this?

With his own two hands -- and    it's not the first time he's    busted up the joint.        I don't care how much he    threatens me, that's the last    time I ever sing "All the Way."    If he wants to hear it again, let    him buy a Sinatra album.
(putting it all
So am I, but you don't see me    "busting up the joint."
She wasn't your wife.
She should've been.
But there is something wrong    here...
That's what I've been telling you.
Klingons usually have a much    shorter mourning period than    humans. They accept death more    readily than we do.
Well, something's driving Worf    cuckoo. Your buddy needs to get    some serious help --
-- and soon. The band's    threatening to quit.
They can't quit -- they're    holograms.
They don't know that.
I'll see what I can do.
Hang in there, pallie.
I'll try, but I think Jadzia's    death has made us all a little    cuckoo.
Dad?
You should be in bed.
Not until you tell me what I    need to know.
I already told you. She's no    one.
You're going to have to do    better than that.
Leave it be, Ben.
I can't. I saw her.
That's impossible.
I'm telling you, I saw her.
You couldn't have...
Dad -- please! Who is she?
I'm sorry, but I don't want to    talk about it.
Dad --
No!
You have to tell me. I have to    know who she is!
Her name was Sarah. I met her    in June of '31.    (a small smile at the    memory)   It was in Jackson Square... she   was, without a doubt, the most   beautiful woman I'd ever seen.
Two months later, we were    married.
Married? You had a wife before    Mom?
It's a little more complicated    than that, Ben. You see...    Sarah was your mother.
Sarah and I were married for two    years. She seemed... very    happy. I certainly was.        Two days after your first    birthday, she disappeared.
What do you mean she disappeared?
She left me.
Why?
I've asked myself that question a    thousand times... I never did    come up with an answer.
And you never found out what    happened to her?
It took me three years, but I    found out. She'd been living in    Australia... working as a holo-   photographer.
I have to speak with her.
You can't.
Damn it, Dad -- I have to.
She's dead. She died in a    hovercraft accident a month    before I tracked her down.         I loved that woman and she loved    me... I know she did.
How come you never told me about    her?
I wanted to... many times. But    you were so young when she left.
I grew up.
I thought that would make it    easier... but it didn't.
That's no excuse.
I know... I'm sorry. But you    see... you and your stepmother    were so close... she made you    laugh like nobody else... I    didn't want anything to get in    the way of that.
I loved Mom... nothing would've    changed that.
She said the same thing.
You should've listened to her.
Life is full of choices... you    make them and hope for the    best...
... sometimes you're right,   sometimes you're not.       I made a mistake.
Yeah... you did.
I still don't understand why the    Prophets would send you a vision    of Sarah.
I came here to clear my head...    to figure out what to do next.
Maybe learning the truth about   my mother is the first step of   that journey.
Well, from here on out, I hope    the Prophets keep their noses    out of my business.
You have any other secrets I    should know about?
Just my gumbo recipe, but I'm    taking that to my grave.
Colonel, I was just coming to    see you.        What is it?
Nothing. I just never thought    I'd see a Romulan eating a jumja    stick.
I was... curious.
And?
It has a... distinct flavor.
Personally, I can't stand them.    Too sweet.
Then you should try a Romulan    osol twist. Very tart.
I'll do that.
I wanted to let you know that a    squadron of warbirds will be    arriving at the station tomorrow    morning for refitting.
I'll tell Chief O'Brien to begin    replicating Romulan system    modules.
Excellent. I had no idea    Bajorans were so efficient.
Coming from a Romulan, that's    quite a compliment.
One more thing... it's about    Bajor's fourth moon.
Derna?
It's uninhabited, correct?
Last time I checked.
Do you think your government    would allow us to set up a    hospital facility there? Too    many of our wounded are dying on    the long journey back to    Romulus.
I'll ask the Council of    Ministers.
I'd appreciate anything you can    do.
You've got to get him talking.    But whatever you do, don't    mention Jadzia. Let him do    that.
I don't think Worf wants to talk    about her.
He may not want to -- but he    needs to. And given the right    circumstances, he will.
(holding up the     bottle)    Well, we have one circumstance in    our favor... Twenty-three oh-one    was a very good year for    bloodwine.
Then I'll leave you to your work.
You're sure one bottle is going    to be enough?
Good-bye, Julian.
Chief?
Mind if I come in?
Why?
(holding up the     bottle)    Because it's been a long time    since we shared one of these.
You have any glasses?
None that are clean.
In that case, who needs glasses?
Cheers.
Ah, that'll warm the cockles.
Very smooth.
Good-night, Chief.
Hold on -- you call that a   visit?
I enjoyed it.
C'mon, Worf. I came to talk.
About what?
Anything you want. Old friends,    the Enterprise...    (trying something     out)    Remember what's-his-name,
Who can forget him?
And those holosuite programs of    his?
The Three Musketeers.
Geordi waving that sword    around...
Ah, that's better.
So what did you find out?
That you should never try to   match drinks with a Klingon.
Yeah, yeah. But what did you    and Worf talk about?
Why do you care?
Because some day, that crazy    Klingon may get tired of    smashing up a holosuite bar and    decide to come down here and    smash up a real one.
So what did you talk about?
A lot of things. His son,   Alexander... growing up in   Russia... the proper way to eat   gagh...
What does any of that have to do    with Jadzia?

Nothing. It wasn't until around    oh-four hundred, when we were    polishing off a third bottle of    bloodwine that we got around to    Jadzia.    (to Quark, re:     raktajino)    You know, this could be sweeter.
Miles! What did he say about    her?
She's not in Sto-vo-kor.
You mean Klingon heaven? What    would she be doing there? She    wasn't a Klingon.
As far as Worf's concerned, she    was. She did join the House of    Martok.
Then what makes him think she's    not in Sto-vo-kor?
For one thing, she never ate the    heart of one of her enemies...
She always was a little    squeamish.
And secondly, she didn't die in    glorious battle.
You mean being murdered in cold    blood by a Pah-wraith doesn't    count?
You want to know what's    bothering Worf or not?
There's more?
There is a way for Worf to    ensure that Jadzia gets into Sto-   vo-kor. He has to win a great    battle in her name.
What if I let him beat me at    tongo?
Not good enough. Unless he has    to carve his way through a    hundred Jem'Hadar to reach the    table.
Why does everything with    Klingons have to involve    bloodshed?
No wonder he's been so    frustrated with convoy duty.    Maybe we can talk to Admiral    Ross...
I can see it now... "Admiral,    could you please send the    Defiant on the most dangerous    mission you can think of --    Jadzia needs to get into Sto-vo-   kor."
Sounds good to me.
Then you ask him.
What about General Martok? He's    due to arrive on the station    tomorrow morning.
Good thinking. Who better than a    Klingon to help a Klingon?
Beautiful night, isn't it?
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: It sure is.
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: You thinking about Sarah?
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Actually, I was thinking about    Jadzia. She was always there to    help me sort things out... I miss    her.
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: I know you do...
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: I came out to give you this...
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: It was Sarah's. I'd like you to    have it. I think she would've,    too.
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Thanks, Dad.
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: There's some kind of writing on    the back.
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: What's the matter?
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: This writing...
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: It's ancient Bajoran.
scene: 49   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: I still don't understand why    Sarah would have a locket with    Bajoran writing on it. I don't    recall her ever mentioning Bajor    to me...
Maybe she didn't know it was    Bajoran... maybe it was a gift    from someone...
Finally, some progress...
What is it?
The inscription... it says "the    Orb of the Emissary."
I never knew there was an "Orb of    the Emissary."
I've never heard of it either --    at least there's no mention of    it in the Bajoran Ancient Texts.
Sounds like you've reached a dead    end...
Not necessarily. What if the Orb    does exist? What if it didn't go    dark like all the others did when    the wormhole disappeared?
If you can find it... you might    be able to use it to contact the    Prophets.
I'm going to find it.
But it could be anywhere... where    do you begin to look?
Tyree.
Why there?
Because that's where I was in the    vision the Prophets sent me.
Are these the latest casualty    reports?
From the Dominion counterattack    in the Chin'toka system. I'm    afraid your people took the    brunt of the assault.

What matters is that we held our    position.        As for our casualties... at    least we now have the hospital    complex on Derna to care for the    wounded. And we have you to    thank, colonel.
All I did was put your request    through to the Council of    Ministers. They made the    decision.
Under your advisement, I'm sure.    All of Romulus owes you a debt    of gratitude.
I'll keep that in mind.
Do you have a moment?
I do for you.
This morning, a Starfleet    transport filled with wounded    was denied permission to dock at    the Romulan hospital complex on    Derna.
The hospital may not be equipped    to treat other species.
I thought the same thing... at    first. But then I noticed that    most of the wounded were Vulcans.
Vulcans and Romulans share a    common physiology.
And a mutual distrust of one    another. That doesn't change    just because they're allies    against the Dominion.
True. But how do you explain    these sensor readings?
High concentrations of trilithium   isotopes...
Which would indicate the presence   of Romulan plasma torpedoes.
I'll look into it.
Worf!
Defend yourself.
So how do you like convoy duty?
I don't.
Good. I was afraid you might be    getting soft.
I need a first officer for a    dangerous mission.
How dangerous?
Dangerous enough to assure Jadzia    a place in Sto-vo-kor.
In that case, you have found your    first officer.
Excellent.
It will be a great victory.
I will make sure of it.
Dad... how many clams do you    think you've cleaned since we    got here?
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: A lot. This was going to be my    last batch. But then I got to    thinking that I'd take a couple    of sacks on the runabout with me    tomorrow... give me something to    do on the way to Tyree.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: You're kidding, right?
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Jake... if I never see another    clam again, it'll be too soon.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Can I help you?
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Emissary... I've come a long way    to see you.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: This is a sacred moment... one    that will be long remembered.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Meeh rak Dorah Pah-wran... Ee-   toi... Velah-slah... Pah-wran   amar... Pah-wran Evak-too...
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: That's ancient Bajoran, isn't it?
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: The Emissary is wise.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Thank you...       ... but right now, the Emissary    has to get back to work.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: You're work is finished. The Orb    that you're seeking... the Orb of    the Emissary...
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Yes?
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: You're never going to find it.
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Grandpa! Grandpa!
scene: 60   EXT. SISKO'S RESTAURANT - BACK ALLEY - NIGHT

quote: Today's special is... shrimp    creole.
Actually, it's barbecued shrimp.
Excuse me...
Where've you been? They told me    you were released from the    hospital two hours ago.
I had to give a statement to    Starfleet Security.
The Bajoran that attacked you...    who was he?
A member of a cult that worships    the Pah-wraiths. They believe    that the disappearance of the    Prophets heralds a new era for    Bajor.
I don't suppose I can talk you    out of going to Tyree.
If you're worried about the Pah-   wraith cult...
I figure you can handle them.    But if the cult knows you're    looking for the Orb of the    Emissary, chances are the Pah-   wraiths do as well. And that    does worry me.
Here's to Worf, hoping his    mission is a success.
Q'apla.
I don't see what you two are so    happy about. An entire Klingon    fleet failed to destroy the    Dominion shipyards at Monac Four.    What makes you think one ship can    do any better?
The element of surprise?
If you ask me, it's not a    mission, it's suicide.
You're beginning to depress me,    Quark.
Why? You're not going.
You can't be serious...
I've never been more serious in    my life. I'm going to help    Jadzia get into Sto-vo-kor.

What makes you think she wants to    spend eternity there? I know I    certainly wouldn't. Imagine what    it must be like -- hoards of    rampaging Klingons, fighting and    singing and belching and    sweating...
(to O'Brien, re:     Quark's)    Sounds like this place on a    Saturday night.
Would you want to spend eternity    here?
Good point. Maybe Jadzia would    prefer to go to... you know,    wherever Trills go when their    time is up.
You don't understand... you   weren't as close to her as I was.    This gives me a chance to honor    her memory and I'm going to take    it. And that, my friend, is my    final word on the subject.
You know what this means don't    you?
I'm risking my life for a very    dubious cause.
No, it means that I'm going to    risk my life for a friend who's   risking his life for a very    dubious cause.
You're going with him?
Somebody has to make sure he    comes back in one piece.
Miles... I don't know what to    say. I'm touched.
You're both touched. You want to    get Jadzia into Sto-vo-kor?    Fine, I'm all for it. But can't    you do something more sensible?    Make a donation in her name or    bribe someone... ?
I'm afraid it doesn't work that    way, Quark.
Be nice if it did...
... the third fleet is requesting    two more attack wings of Romulan    warbirds.
That shouldn't be a problem.
Good. Now if --
Senator -- I have a message for    you from the Bajoran Council of    Ministers.
We're in the middle of a    meeting, colonel...
I'm sorry, sir. But this can't
Apparently, we're no longer    welcome on Derna.
(surprised at the    news)   They want to shut down the   hospital?
The hospital isn't the problem.
Then what is?
The seven thousand plasma    torpedoes that the Romulans have    secretly deployed there.
Is this true, Senator?
The weapons are for defensive    purposes only.
My government doesn't agree.    You're to begin an evacuation    immediately.
I'm afraid that's impossible.
Let's try to stay calm. I'm    sure we can reach some kind of    compromise.
Not this time, admiral. My    government considers the Romulan    presence on Derna to be a direct    threat to Bajor.
This is ridiculous. I regret    not informing your government    about our weapon emplacements.    But I didn't think it was    necessary -- we're your ally.
Then remove the weapons.
That would leave the hospital    unprotected.
Bajor will guarantee its safety.
I'm afraid that's not acceptable.
Either you remove those weapons,    or we will.
See that Gul Yaltar of the Third    Order gets this immediately.
Have you heard? The Romulans    have taken over a Bajoran moon    and heavily fortified it.
My guess is the Bajorans aren't    happy about that.
Would you be? This is the kind    of "unfortunate" situation that    can destroy an alliance.
That would be a pity.
Romulans... they're so    predictably treacherous.
What's going on? Why's the    restaurant closed?
I'm going on vacation. To   Tyree.
We're coming with you, Dad.
Are you both crazy?
Apparently, it runs in the   family.
I suppose you're already packed.
I even remembered my toothbrush.
Nothing I hate more than turning   away a customer.
I'm sorry, we're closed.
That's all right, Mister Sisko --   I'm not hungry. I'm here to see   Ben.
You're in luck. Five more   minutes and he'd have been gone.
(somewhat unsure of     herself)   Hello, Benjamin.
Do I know you?
It's me... Dax.
